items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.05
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and George Sanchez, Coordinator of Student Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Plan for Expelled Youth
	 
As mandated by Education Code 48926, each county superintendent of schools in counties that operate community schools pursuant to Section 1980, in conjunction with superintendents of the school districts within the county, shall develop a plan for providing education services to all expelled students in that county.  The plan shall be adopted by the governing board of each school district within the county and by the county board of education.
	 
The plan shall enumerate existing education alternatives for expelled students, identify gaps in educational services to expelled students, and strategies for filling those service gaps.  The plan shall also identify alternative placements for students who are expelled and placed in district community day school programs, but who fail to meet the terms and conditions of their rehabilitation plan or who pose a danger to other district students, as determined by the governing board.
	 
Each county superintendent of schools, in conjunction with the superintendents of the school districts, shall submit to the Superintendent of Public Instruction the county plan for providing educational services to all expelled students in the county no later than June 30, 2013, and shall submit a triennial update to the plan to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, including the outcome data pursuant to Section 48916.1, on June 30th thereafter.
	 
Per Education Code 48916.1, at the time an expulsion of a student is ordered, the governing board of the school district shall ensure that an educational program is provided to the student who is subject to the expulsion order for the period of the expulsion.  Except for students expelled pursuant to subdivision (d) of Section 48915 (related to the five (5) offenses mandatory for recommendation of expulsion/to expel), the governing board is required to implement the provisions of this section only to the extent funds are appropriated for this purpose in the annual Budget Act or other legislation, or both.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the Santa Clara County Office of Education/East Side Union High School District's Plan for Expelled Youth.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item 8.06
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, and Gina Ortiz, Principal, San Jose Conservation Corps
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Measures E and I Distribution for San Jose Conservation Corps and Charter School
	 
Under Proposition 39, San Jose Conservation Corps and Charter School (SJCC) is eligible for the District’s Bond Measure E proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to improve District buildings and properties and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  On February 19, 2009, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure E Prioritization List that allocated funds to SJCC (Board item 13.03).  On March 24, 2011, the Board approved a Measure E base allocation of $740 per one time maximum ADA for high school age District resident students attending charter schools within the District for technology and equipment procurement; the approved total maximum distribution to SJCC is $201,280 (Board item 13.01).  In addition, the Board approved SJCC’s Technology Plan, and authorized distribution of $74,473.60 to proceed with the purchasing and implementation of that plan.  
	 
To date, $275 million of the Measure E $349 million bond authorization has been issued (78.68%).  On June 11, 2013 (Board Item 15.02), the Board authorized the allocation of $74 million of Measure I funds for Measure I uses that would also restore previously Board-approved Measure E site allocations in the same amount.  The entire approved amount for SJCC can now be distributed.  The balance to be distributed is $126,806.40 ($201,280 less previously distributed $74,473.60).
	 
Board Approved Amount
Previously Distributed
SJCC Current Request
District Recommendation
$201,280
$74,473.60
$269,600
$126,806.40
	 
	 
SJCC has identified a need for furniture, fixtures and equipment to support instruction, students and staff.  SJCC will be presenting their plan to remedy this resource deficiency by receiving Measure E and I funds (Attachment A).
	 
SJCC serves 491 students.  Of those students, 378 reside within East Side Union High School District boundaries.
	 
The District recommendation is based on facilities standards for classrooms and typical furniture and equipment provisions for students and staff.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:                                                   
$126,806.40           
                       
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E bond funds ($83,888.77)
Measure I bond funds ($42,917.63)
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve distribution of furniture, fixtures and equipment, funded by Measure E ($83,888.77) and I ($42,917.63) bond funds, to SJCC in an amount not to exceed $126,806.40.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve distribution of furniture, fixtures and equipment, funded by Measures E ($83,888.77) and I ($42,917.63) bond funds, to SJCC in an amount not to exceed $126,806.40.

Item:  8.07
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:  
					 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator, Randy Phelps, Director of Information Technology, and Dan Tracy, Consultant from NW Imaging Analysts
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of the Result of the Districtwide Copier Equipment and Services RFP#GP081213   
	 
In the presentation we will be going over the results of the Districtwide Copier Equipment and Services RFP#GP081213.  The following companies responded to the District’s copier solicitation:
	 
Vendor:
Copier Manufacturer:
MBS Business Systems
Konica Minolta
Konica Minolta Business Center
Konica Minolta
Sharp Business Systems
Sharp
Ricoh USA
Ricoh
Caltronics
Konica Minolta
Pacific Office Automation
Sharp & Konica Minolta
Toshiba America
Toshiba
Ray Morgan Company
Canon
	 
At the May 9th Board meeting, the Board approved the hire of Northwest Imaging Analysts as recommended by the District’s Internal Audit Committee to help facilitate and evaluate its copier replacement for the entire district.  Northwest Imaging Analysts and District Administration worked together to analyze the District’s needs, prepare a Request for Proposals, and evaluate the proposals to replace the entire copier fleet with new leased state of the art Multifunctional Devices. 
	 
A Request for Proposals (RFP) (GP081213) was released on May 17, 2013 and published in the Post Record on May 20 and 28, 2013. The RFP was posted onto the ESUHSD’s website and was mailed to 14 known vendors. Northwest Imaging Analysts received questions and held a conference call with all interested vendors on June 5, 2013.
	 
Proposals were received from eight firms and two “no bid” responses.  All proposals were considered in the evaluation process.  Northwest Imaging Analysts thoroughly evaluated the proposals and the equipment specifications to ESUHSD’s requirements and scored the proposals according to the criteria as stipulated in the RFP.  Below is a summary of the pricing compared to ESUHSD’s current pricing, it is the Administration’s recommendation that we award the RFP to Ricoh in an estimated annual lease/maintenance cost of $322,000.00 with tax.  
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
Existing Copier Maintenance Cost
$239,385.56
New Estimated Maintenance Cost
$131,683.20
Existing Copier Lease Cost
$102,578.48
New Copier/MFD Lease
$163,783.56
Estimated Total Annual Copier Cost
$341,964.04
New Estimated Annual MFP Costs
$295,466.76
plus tax
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
($19,964.04) estimated annual decrease in expenses
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Site Discretionary-General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:  1) Award Request for Proposals RFP#GP081213 to Ricoh USA for the lease and maintenance service of ESUHSD's Copier Equipment in an estimated annual savings amount of $19,964.00.  2) To authorize Administration to negotiate with Ricoh USA for a 48-month lease for the MFP Equipment and/or to negotiate with other banks to obtain the best pricing for the leasing of the ESUHSD's MFP Equipment specified in the RFP #GP081213.  3)  Term of the lease to be August 1, 2013 through and including June 30, 2017.  4)  To delegate authority to the Superintendent or designee to enter into additional leased as needed to meet the needs of the District and to modify such Lease Agreement during the term as needed.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. on the Provisions of the Charter School Petition of Latino College Preparatory Academy II to Consider the Level of Support for Each Petition by Teachers Employed by the District, Other Employees of the District, and Parents
BACKGROUND
	 
The Latino College Preparatory Academy II petition was submitted to the board on May 9, 2013. Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition to the board and a decision on authorization within 60 days unless an extension is agree upon by both parties. Both parties have agreed to an extension, where the Public Hearing will be held on June 27, 2013 and the decision on authorization will be made at the August 22, 2013 Board Meeting. 
	 
The purpose of the public hearing is for the Governing Board of the school district to consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold public hearing to consider level of support for the petition submitted by Latino College Preparatory Academy II.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item: 9.03
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Adopt the Annual Budget for 2013-14
		 
The 2013-14 Adopted budget reflects the actions and input of the Governing Board, Superintendent, stakeholders, and staff to develop a budget that is responsive to district needs and priorities.  The final budget was prepared taking into account all changes relative to the Governor’s May revision proposal.  This budget year has proved to be especially challenging given the proposed change in the funding formula from revenue limit to the Local Control Funding Formula (LCFF).  In addition, information regarding the LCFF has changed on a constant basis.  In spite of all the challenges, the district has managed to develop a budget that recognizes new revenue from the LCFF.  The district can now begin to have welcomed conversations around establishing priorities for possible restoration of some programs, services, and resources that were lost during the economic downturn.   
		 
The district is planning to submit a 45 day budget revision to the adopted budget as a result of the State’s budget adoption actions.  The district will still need to be vigilant in managing deficit spending and will need to closely monitor future spending to ensure spending is balanced. The district will continue to closely monitor and report on the State’s budget circumstances and how it impacts the district as information becomes available.         
		 
The 2013-14 budget indicates that the district is recommending that a positive budget be adopted based on the district’s ability to maintain sufficient reserves for the upcoming and two subsequent fiscal years. The attached budget book with executive summary provides a more detailed analysis of the FY 2013-14 district budget and required State SACS reporting forms.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and adopt the annual budget for 2013-14 with a positive certification for the 2013-14 fiscal year and two subsequent years.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  11.03
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Board Member Compensation/Adjustments to Compensation per Education Code Section 35120
		 
		 
		 
This item addresses the Board Members’ monthly compensation allowable under the Education Code for the 2013-2014 school year and requests and recommends:
		 
Board action reducing the monthly stipend for the 2013-2014 school year as required by the Education Code in light of a recent reduction in ADA; and
Approve a 5% increase in the monthly stipend (based on the new, lower monthly rate) as provided in the Education Code.
		 
Monthly Stipend Amount
		 
The calculation of Board members’ monthly compensation is governed by Education Code section 35120.  Monthly compensation to Board members during any school year is based upon average daily attendance during the prior school year.  Pursuant to the Education Code, the maximum monthly compensation District Board members could receive would be $750.00.  (However, on May 6, 2010, the Board voted to take a 10% reduction in its monthly compensation consistent with budget cuts affecting employees as a result of the State’s economic crisis.  Therefore, as a result of that 2010 action Board members currently receive monthly compensation of $675.00.)  Education Code section 35120(a)(3) provides:
		 
“In any school district in which the average daily attendance for the prior school year was 60,000, or less, but more than 25,000, each member of the city board of education or the governing board of the district who actually attends all meetings held may receive as compensation for his or her services a sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750) in any month.”  (Emphasis added)
		 
However, if ADA for the prior school year is more than 10,000 but less than 25,001, then the Board member monthly stipend is governed Section 35120(a)(4) which provides:
		 
“In any school district in which the average daily attendance for the prior school year was 25,000, or less, but more than 10,000, each member of the city board of education or the governing board of the district who actually attends all meetings held may receive as compensation for his or her services a sum not to exceed four hundred dollars ($400) in any month.”
		 
District staff has calculated ADA for the 2012-2013 school year at 22,514.51.  (See Attachment 1)  ADA for the 2012-2013 school year for Adult Education, which is calculated separately, totaled 1440.16.  (See Attachment 2)  The District does not report or receive apportionments for ADA for charter school students or MetroED.
		 
 For purposes of calculating Board member compensation, Education Code Section 35120(a)(9) further provides:
		 
“For the purposes of providing compensation pursuant to paragraphs (1) to (7), inclusive, average daily attendance for the prior school year may be increased by a school district’s percentage of excused absences reported for the 1996–97 fiscal year.” (Emphasis added)
		 
During the 1996-1997 fiscal year excused absences accounted for 0.04426% of the District’s reported ADA (955.58 ADA for excused absences out of 21,589.34 total ADA).
		 
Based on the above data, ADA for purposes of calculating Board member compensation for the 2013-2014 school year pursuant to Education Codes section 35120 is determined as follows:
		 
           
2012-2013 Avg. Daily Attendance (Attach. 1)
22,514.51
2012-2013 Adult Ed. Avg. Daily Attend. (Attach. 2)
1,440.16
Adjustment/Increase for 1996-1997 excused absences per Educ. Code section 35120(a)(9)1
996.49 (22,514.51 x 0.04426)
Total Avg. Daily Attendance per §35120
24,951.16
		 
Pursuant to Education Code section 35120(a)(4), and because average daily attendance for 2012-2013 was less than 25,000, the monthly compensation for Board Members for 2013-2014 should be reduced to $400.00, effective as of July 1, 2013.
                                   
Statutorily Allowable Increase to Board Member Compensation 
		 
The reduction in compensation to $400 per month will result in a 47% reduction in monthly compensation to Board Members below the statutorily allowed amount ($750).  Education Code section 35120(e) provides:
		 
“On an annual basis, the governing board may increase the compensation of individual board members beyond the limits delineated in this section, in an amount not to exceed 5 percent based on the present monthly rate of compensation. Any increase made pursuant to this section shall be effective upon approval by the governing board.”
		 
Notwithstanding section 35120(e), it appears that the Board has never taken any action to implement a 5% increase to the monthly compensation as allowed by law.  On that basis, Administration recommends that, once the Board has approved the reduction in the monthly compensation to $400.00 consistent with the above analysis resulting from the reduction in ADA, the Board then approve a 5% increase to the Board Member compensation to take effect July 1, 2013, resulting in a new monthly compensation per Board Member of $420.00 pursuant to Education Code section 35120(e).
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Estimated $19,800 in savings to the General Fund
                                                                                              
FUNDING SOURCE:
Unrestricted General Fund
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board:
Approve the reduction in Board Member monthly compensation from $750 to $400 pursuant to Education Code section 35120, effective July 1, 2013; and
Approve a 5% increase in Board Member monthly compensation to $420 per month effective July 1, 2013, pursuant to Education Code section 35120(e).
â
1The 0.04426 adjustment factor is applied to the 22,514.51 ADA reported by the District at P-2, not including Adult Education, since the 1996-1997 report submitted by the District to the State calculated ADA for excused absences only as to grades 9-12, continuation education and special education students, and did not include Adult Education students.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.03
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Program Improvement Year 4 School Alternative Governance Plans
	 
Local Educational Agencies (LEA) who have schools in Program Improvement, Year 4, are responsible for working with the schools to develop a restructuring/alternative governance plan. Yerba Buena High School is in Year 4 and have been working with the district to analyze progress and construct a plan. 
	 
Schools in Program Improvement Year 4 are required to do the following:
Create a District and School Liaison Team (DSLT).  This team leads the school through the PI Year 4 planning process and chooses a restructuring/alternative governance plan. A  DSLT was created at both sites following the state suggested composition, that is, supervisor of the principal, curriculum and instruction administrator, classroom teachers, member of the school’s advisory council, parents, and other informed individuals. Each DSLT met twice and followed the CDE recommended protocol to select appropriate alternative governance option(s) and revise the Single Plan for Student Achievement.
Allow adequate opportunity for teachers and parents to comment before taking action. With assistance from committee members, information was shared and stakeholders had opportunities to comment on suggested plans.
Choose one of the four following options as their restructuring/alternative governance structure. 
Close the school and reopen it as a charter school.
Replace all or most of the school staff (which may include the principal) who are relevant to the failure to make AYP.
Enter into a contract with an entity, such as a private management company with a demonstrated record of effectiveness, to operate the public school.
Implement any other major restructuring of the school’s governance arrangement that makes fundamental reforms and leads to improved student achievement. 
After completing the CDE recommended protocol, Yerba Buena selected D, that is, to implement an alternative governance structure.
	 
Yerba Buena’s school plan for alternative governance structure - The main focus areas of their alternative governance structure are as follows:
Implementation of the 7 period day to increase the school's capacity to offer advisory periods, intervention services and allow the implementation of additional collaboration time to incorporate the Professional learning community.
Implement Professional Learning Communities with the goal of analyzing subject and department level data in regards to student achievement.
Implement common assessments in all core subject areas.
Implement Linked Learning/Pathways Model that will divide the school into two school of focus, Humanities and STEM.  Entering freshman will have the ability to choose between one of two schools.
Ensure that the school’s Single Plan for Student Achievement reflects the alternative governance structure chosen above.
The alternative governance structure is represented in Yerba Buena’s Single Plan for Student Achievement.
	 
The DSLT will continue to meet on a regular basis at both high schools to look at student achievement data and monitor the alternative governance plan. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION: 
It is recommended that the Governing Board Approve the Alternative Governance Structure at Yerba Buena High School.

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion of Graduation, Dropout and A-G Completion
	 
The Instructional Division prepared a presentation on student progress towards meeting UC/CSU A-G entrance requirements as well as an analysis of the 12th grade dropouts of 2011/12. The 2012/13 juniors were the first freshman class to begin high school under the board resolution that established A-G and Career as the default curriculum.  The presentation compares the percent of juniors in 2010/11, 2011/12, and 2012/13 on "on track" to complete the A-G requirements by the end of their senior year. The data compares juniors district-wide with Hispanic juniors, and Asian juniors. Dropouts of the class of 2011/12 are analyzed and compared to the class of 2010/11 to determine any change to the percent of completer dropouts. Completer dropouts are students who complete their 12th grade year of high school but do not earn a diploma.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for the Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO for the 2013-2014 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2013-2014 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; and contract language amendments to Article 9000 – Leaves and absences.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action for Use of Facilities Lease Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Valley Community College for the Accel Program
			 
East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to approve a Facilities Lease Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Valley Community College District for the Agreement term of September 1, 2013 through and including June 30, 2016 for the non-exclusive use of two Classrooms, one office space, and two storage areas at San Jose/Evergreen Valley Community College District.  
			 
ESUHSD had been renting 10 portables on San Jose/Evergreen Valley Community College’s campus for the past eight years. Those portables were used for the Accel, Genesis, and the Valdez programs.  However, ESUHSD has determined that our need no longer requires us to continue to lease ten portables.  After consultation with ESUHSD Business and Instructional Division San Jose/Evergreen Valley Community College Administration is recommending that we vacate the ten portables and move the Accel program onto the main college campus and into main classroom setting.
			 
Administration has negotiated the use of two classrooms, two storage areas, and one office space for the annual cost of $50,750.00.  Previously ESUHSD paid $118,114.24 annually for the ten portables.
			 
School/Department/Manager:
Evergreen Valley High School/Lauren Kelly, Principal
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$67,364.24 Estimated annual savings

Capital Facilities Fund
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve a Facilities Lease Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Valley Community College District for the of term of August 1, 2013 through June 1, 2014 with two automatic renewals through June 2016 based on a mutual written agreement of the parties.  The agreement for the non-exclusive use of two classrooms, two storage areas, and one office space for the estimated annual amount of $50,750.00 and to delegate authority to the Superintendent or designee to modify such Lease Agreement during the term as needed.

TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Award Professional Service Agreement for (RFQ/P-25-12-13) Performance Audit Services for Proposition 39 Bond Measures G & E
	 
On June 4, 2013 Capital Purchasing, under the direction of Administration, solicited services from auditing firms to conduct a Performance Audit for Bond Fund Measure G and Measure E starting 2009/2010 to present. The last report of such a comprehensive performance audit was reported in 2008 for years 2004 through 2007. In 2009, Santa Clara County Office of Education (SCCOE) engaged FCMAT to perform an “extraordinary” audit.  The final report of the finding with recommendations was issued in January, 2010, and it covered year up to 2008/2009 for Measures A, E, and G.
	 
The scope of services requested is to include an overall evaluation of the bond program, a list of bond areas needing improvements and recommendations for improvements in the following areas:
Bond Management Plan/Program
Design and Construction Schedules and Timelines
Proposed Design and Construction Cost Budgets
Payment Procedures
Use of Best Practices regarding the Planning  and Construction of School Facilities
Bond Management Structure including Adequacy of Program Management Personnel
Procedures for Claims Avoidance
School Management and Construction Budgets
Change Order/Claims Procedures and Results
Current Programmatic Goals to ensure compliance with State law, guidelines, and funding formulas and District guidelines for bidding and procurement.
“Best practices” for management of procurement of materials and services in order to promote and increase efficient use of Bond Funds.
Evaluation of Public Outreach Program
Effectiveness of communication channels among all stakeholders within the Bond Program
	 
The audit findings will be assessed and evaluated by the Superintendent.  Following that assessment, the Superintendent will present his recommendation to the Board for program management services for Measures G, E and I.  The proposed timeline for this process is as follows:
July 1, 2013 - Consultant begins to provide services;
End of August, 2013 - Meet with consultant for final closing remarks;
September 3, 2013 - Meet with consultant  to review “draft” report, and provide comments;
September 6, 2013 – Receive “final draft” from consultant; 
September 9, 2013 -  Consultant meets with Council and staff to review final recommendations;
September 12, 2013 – Receive “final report” from consultant to submit to the Board;
September 19, 2013 – Final Report presented to the Board of Trustees.
October 17, 2013 – Superintendent recommendation for PM Services for Measures I, E & G
Staff solicited five (5) auditing firms that perform these services and two (2) firms submitted proposals with one firm declining to respond due to being at maximum workload capacity for their firm.  The timeline for soliciting these services didn’t follow the formal solicitation process outlined in the District’s Administrative Regulation 3311.  Administration requests the Board to waive this procurement requirement due to the time restraints.
	 
Proposals were evaluated by the Senior Manager of Internal Controls as well as the Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and the Capital Purchasing staff members for completeness (inclusion and execution of required forms); professional qualifications and relevant experience of the proposed team members; and current and previous client satisfaction.  Fees were reviewed and determined to be competitive.  
	 
	 
Proposal Results:
					 
Consultant
					 
Fees
Total School Solutions
$161,200.00
KPMG, LLP
$259,600.00 (estimate)
Vicenti, Lloyd, Stutzman, LLP
Declined to propose
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
$161,200.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measures G & E 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
(1) Approve the Professional Service Agreement for Performance Audit Services for Proposition 39 Bond Measures G & E to Total School Solutions for three (3) months commencing on July 01, 2013, and terminating on September 30, 2013; and
(2) Waive the formal solicitation process required by Administration Regulation 3311 for this RFQ/P-25-12-13 due to time restraints.

SUBJECT:

Seville Group, Inc. Administration is recommending a four month extension of the Measure E program management agreement with SGI to allow sufficient time for completion of the performance audit and for Administration to complete its review, analysis and recommendation to the Board.
	 
In addition and as part of the proposed amendment, Administration is recommending approval of a change order under the Measure E contract in an amount not to exceed $139,000 to engage SGI’s services in the preliminary planning for the Measure I program during the four month extension period to include the following deliverables:
	 
Initial project priority lists by site and by equity distribution criteria;
Initial project work scopes for Measure I;
Planning, assistance and advise on project phasing and delivery;
A peer review of construction cost data provided by the District’s Cost Consultant;
A preliminary program schedule;
Project Brief Development; and
Facilitation of meetings, presentation and required historical context.
	 
All portions of this work, if approved by the Board, would be charged and allocated to Measure I.
	 
	 
*Agreement to be provided when available

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item 15.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Measure I Equity Distribution
	 
An equity distribution methodology was Board approved to fairly allocate Measure I funding in accordance with District priorities (June 11, 2013, Board Item 15.03).  The methodology is a weighted allocation of funds to comprehensive high schools in accordance with the following three categories:
API/SED/EL Distribution:  the greatest share is allocated to the schools with the lowest Academic Performance Index scores, the highest numbers of Socioeconomically Disadvantaged subgroup members, and the highest numbers of English Learner subgroup members.  This combination of published data that is readily accessible and understood is equally weighted to derive the rankings.  Administration proposes a weight of 30% in this first category.
The first Measure E category was Academic Performance Distribution (30%), wherein the greatest share was allocated to the lowest academic performers.  For Measure I this category remains consistent with a proposed weight of 30%.
SPED Distribution:  the greatest share is allocated to schools with the highest number of students qualifying for special education services.  Special education has unique facilities needs with associated costs; this allocation category recognizes that schools with the greatest number of students qualifying for special education services also has the greatest need for higher cost facilities to support special education curriculum.   Administration proposes a weight of 10% in this second category.
The second Measure E category was Bond Share Distribution (30%), wherein the greatest share was allocated to campuses that received the least amounts of previous bond measure monies.  Funding equity between schools was achieved, therefore this category is now focused on SPED with a proposed weight of 10%.
Permanent Modernized Capacity Distribution:  the greatest share is allocated to schools with the greatest need to eliminate portables and modernize original permanent spaces.  This goal of the 2004 Facilities Master Plan has not yet been fully realized, and remains an important aspect of achieving the best possible learning environment.  There are currently in excess of 260 owned and/or leased portable, temporary buildings at our school sites, many of which are approaching and/or exceeding their intended service life.  Funds expended on maintaining and repairing portable inventory are not as prudent an investment, due to the ultimately temporary nature of portable building construction.  This Measure I distribution category aligns funding with modernization of permanent facilities.  Administration proposes a weight of 35% in this first category.
The third Measure E category was Academic Master Plan Distribution (20%), wherein funds were allocated to specific projects based on School Site Council priorities.  For Measure I a weight of 35% is proposed to provide greater emphasis on modernizing permanent facilities not touched by previous bonds. 
Additionally, the methodology provides an allocation of funds to:
Alternative Education Distribution
The Alternative Education Distribution for Measure E was 10%.  A significant amount of work was accomplished in Measure E in this category.  Although the proposed allocation of 15% is an increased percentage, it is based on a significantly smaller dollar value.  The proposed allocation is based on projected needs anticipated to be identified as a result of the District’s strategic planning initiative, which may include special education, small but necessary schools, and other alternative education components.
Technology Distribution
The Technology Distribution for Measure E was 10%.  For Measure I this category remains consistent with a proposed weight of 10%.
The Measure I Equity Distribution worksheet (Attachment A) shows Administration’s proposed weight (indicated as a percentage share) to be allocated in each category.  Based on the rankings of each site within each category, the worksheet indicates the proposed Measure I dollars that would be distributed to each site, by category and cumulatively.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$34,085,000                                                   
                                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure I general obligation bond funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the distribution of $34,085,000 of Measure I funds to District sites in accordance with the Equity Distributions – Measure I depicted on Attachment A.

Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
				A
				B
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

SUBJECT:
Receive Local Education Agency Plan 2012 - Progress Update June 2013
	 
The Board of Trustees approved the new Local Education Agency Plan (LEAP) in June 2012.  Each year districts are required to submit an update on the LEAP to the Board of Trustees showing progress made on goals and activities that support these goals.  The majority of the data required to evaluate the progress made on the LEAP goals does not become available until the fall so the update to the Board of Trustees will be done in two parts.  The first part consists of an update on the progress made on the activities included in the plan.  The second update will be submitted in the fall evaluating the progress made towards the goals in LEAP.  The document being submitted to the board June 27, 2013 is the update on the activities supporting the goals of the LEAP.

SUBJECT:
Receive and Adopt First Reading of Amended Board ByLaw  9270E
		 
		 
		 
The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories.  The change reflected in the attached draft proposed revised Board ByLaw 9270E clarify a new position to be included within the category of positions required to submit disclosures.  The District is required to submit the proposed approved changes to the Santa Clara County Counsel.
		 
		 
		 
		 
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board receive and adopt amended Board ByLaw 9270E.
